awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Embedding Public Engagement with Science at Long-Term Ecological Research Sites
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. This project will embed public engagement with science (PES) into the cultures and practices of two Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) sites:  the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest in New Hampshire and the Harvard Forest in Massachusetts.  The goals are 1) to build knowledge about the mutual learning between scientists and adult stakeholders in face-to-face engagement setting and 2) to develop evidence-based practices in the content of place-based ecosystem research. This is a collaborative project of 3 universities (Michigan State University, Harvard, and CUNY)  and the two LTERs.

Two primary research questions guide this work.  First, how willing are participating scientists to take part in PES? What are their attitudes and beliefs about whether engagement can be effective and whether they have the necessary skills? Second, how willing are participating scientists to build relationships with stakeholders using normed tactics?  Both qualitative and quantitative methods will be used to collect evidence including semi-structured interviews and surveys.  A general set of hypothesis include that there will be positive changes in LTER scientists willingness to participate in PES, attitudes, and efficacy beliefs.

por.por_cntn:
Scientists and the leaders of scientific research programs increasingly recognize the importance of public engagement with science (PES). We define PES broadly, as an umbrella concept that encompasses the activities that scientists and scientific organizations undertake to communicate and engage with community members, stakeholders, decision makers, and other publics. PES scholarship emphasizes the importance of intentional, meaningful, two-way interactions between scientific actors and members of these publics, that over time, foster mutual understanding and trust, which are essential outcomes for science to serve societal needs. From 2017 to 2021, our team led a research and development project to advance evidence-based PES within Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) programs, using the Hubbard Brook Ecosystem Study in New Hampshire and the Harvard Forest in Massachusetts as pilot sites. Our vision driving this work is to embed PES into the cultures, practices, and institutions of environmental research. We envision multiple pathways for engagement, integrated throughout the research cycle, that nurture meaningful relationships, produce societally relevant scientific questions, shape the context in which these questions are addressed, and transform the use of results by public audiences, decision-makers, and the scientific community. From this lens, PES becomes a transformative force, not only on the individuals who participate, but on the process of science itself, and the role of science in broader society.

 

Toward this vision, the PES@LTERs project focused on three main goals: (1) building foundational knowledge about scientist behaviors and beliefs related to PES participation and strategy; (2) understanding the impacts of PES activities on participating scientists, stakeholders, and community members; and (3) developing a suite of evidence-based PES practices and support structures that can be deployed within LTER programs and other scientific research organizations. This work integrated social science research, practical design and development, and external evaluation, in a nested project design. Two inner shells of design and development work advanced core practices and established relationships across science society boundaries, and an outer shell of research, evaluation, and meaning-making advanced foundational knowledge about PES and its role in scientific research organizations. 

 

The core of the design and development work involved two dialogue-based synthesis projects to co-produce knowledge about locally relevant issues with scientists, community members, stakeholders, and decision-makers. One project, led by the team at Harvard Forest, co-produced an online, map-based tool to explore evidence-based future scenarios of land-use and landscape change in New England. This tool, the New England Landscape Futures Explorer (NELF Explorer), was launched in March 2019 online at https://newenglandlandscapes.org/. Five community groups in Maine, Connecticut, Vermont, Massachusetts, and Rhode Island have now adopted the NELF Explorer to advance conservation planning and informal learning about the future of land. A second project, led by the team at Hubbard Brook, launched a collaborative investigation to understand the resilience of forest ecosystems in New Hampshire and the linkages between ecological resilience and the resilience of human communities, particularly in the rural northern counties of the state. This work included several rounds of in-person and online dialogue sessions with scientists and stakeholders, as well as several rounds of interviews with community volunteers in 18 rural communities. This work produced a new scientific analysis of changing ecological resilience in the northern forest, which is currently in review with a scientific journal, as well as two resilience training sessions that reached 175 community leaders.

 

Drawing on these projects, as well as prior related work, we produced a new framework for embedding evidence-based PES within environmental research organizations called the ECO Framework. ECO stands for formative engagement, co-design and co-production, and broader outreach, three essential and interacting modes of operation for effective PES. We developed and shared the ECO Framework iteratively with PES practitioners and scientists over a series of workshops and conference presentations over a three-year period.

 

Our research efforts focused on a series of surveys and interviews with scientists to understand their beliefs and behaviors related to PES. This work, grounded in the Theory of Planned Behavior and Integrated Behavioral Model, was based on the idea that by understanding scientist beliefs about PES (e.g., perceived benefits, norms, and self-efficacy), we should be able to design better interventions to improve their PES behaviors. Although we initially focused on scientist beliefs about their individual PES participation, we shifted our focus to scientist beliefs about shared PES strategies within their organizations and working with PES professionals, which we learned from our interviews were important factors in understanding and advancing cultures of PES within research organizations. The key findings of our research suggest that the PES and science communication fields should put more attention on how scientists think about and work with PES professionals and how they develop shared PES strategies. This is a shift from the fields current focus on science communication skill-building for individual scientists via training programs.
